newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks end lower on U.S. rate fears.
newsitem.headline: French stocks end lower on U.S. rate fears.

text.p: French shares finished lower on Friday, with traders citing concerns over a possible further rise in U.S. interest rates.

The market took a tumble after U.S. data showed a stronger-than-expected rise in core March producer prices and retail sales were revised upward for February, fuelling fears of inflationary pressure and the need for a tightening by the Fed.

The blue-chip CAC-40 index closed down 33.41 points or 1.28 percent at 2,574.56. The index was up 2.25 percent on the week. The CAC-40 futures contract was down 39 at 2,567 from Thursday's close. Volume was 5.47 billion francs.
Wall Street and other centres fell sharply on the statistics, and the CAC duly followed.
"In period of uncertainty and in low volumes, the market follows Wall Street," said one operator.

On the downside, various brokers see support at 2,550 but below the 2,550/2,500 area, strong support was seen at 2,450. However, one broker said once a correction had taken place, the index could end the year at 2,800.
Accor was among rare risers, which added 2.55 percent to 846, viewed as a cheap buy, with revaluation potential under the new head, Jean-Marc Espalioux.
PSA Peugeot Citroen was up 1.28 percent at 634, slipstreaming behind strong Volkswagen first quarter sales.
Bouygues was up 0.36 percent. Lyonnaise des Eaux chairman Jerome Monod said in a newspaper interview Bouygues was one of companies it was talking to for a telecommunications partner.
Lyonnaise was suspended, as was Cie de Suez.

Suez confirmed the board would ask shareholders to approve a merger plan with Lyonnaise and set a dividend of 24.6 francs per share, totalling 3.8 billion francs. Suez is also cancelling five percent of its share capital.
